a706e64YccclDeTvey-iXA.text: Tasty spring roll salad; will definitely be going back to try the summer rolls. My order was takeaway, but the atmosphere inside looked quite nice too. One star less just because I thought the portion was a bit small for the price...

inNxPrF1p1GcFpRFUKqtyg.text: I discovered the restaurant 2 years ago and it has been my favourite Vietnamese since. I'm always going for the pho with some fresh rolls as a starter. It's delicious and fresh and the staff is very friendly. During lunch time it gets quite busy, but waiting times aren't long and it's definitely worth waiting a few minutes.  Also try the freshly made juices they're very tasty!

MmpzNYWBV3FZXlFDk4a0XQ.text: As i havent  had vietnamese food that was memorable before I thought this was very nice.  so fresh and clean (im talking about the food) it made me feel very healthy eating the massive bowl of soup with noodles and pork/prawns and the rolls were generous size and morish .  I chose the right food from the menu to start my vietnamese experience. The place looks new, there is a huge fridge with soft drinks  and juices to help yourself . they dont serve alcohol but you can byog.. good service and good prices..

ubjMYetgj2QCK40dTVwIPA.text: I only come here for the Vietnamese baguettes, so I can't give a complete review of their food and service. But the baguettes are pretty much the only reason to visit, and their only point of distinction from the other Vietnamese restaurants nearby in Shoreditch.We're talking cheap, wholesome, hot sandwiches that you just pick up and eat on the go. My recommendation is the classic grilled chicken satay, packed together with tangy chilli sauce, carrots, onions and cucumber in a sweet crusty roll, but there're plenty of other tasty fillings to choose from. My eye has often lingered over the grilled prawns and the caramel shredded pork, for example, but then I always revert back to my standard choice.As other folks have pointed out, it gets mentally frantic at lunchtime. Queues snake out the door, or orders get mixed up, or supplies on the sandwich counter run low. It's best to pick your moment before visiting, but it's certainly worth a visit.

tptwq33BC9a6IWNDFB0gsA.text: The Pho here is generally pretty good and since it's close to work I've had lunch here quite a lot.  It gets REALLY busy around 1pm so I think the best time to go is about 12.  The service is generally good and the food doesn't disappoint.

vHG8pN8Z0z6c0LGoUdZdmQ.text: i've been searching for some good pho.  i stop by banh mi bay with some coworkers to satisfy my craving for soup noodles.  i got the beef pho.  i like my beef raw and on the side, but they don't play that game.  it's okay i still ate it all.  the broth was delicious even without much loved cilantro.  basil helped.  i'll be back to try the sammies.  they really should have made a take out window so queues for takeout could be set outside to avoid the jam in the dining room.  despite the jam, the service is quick and speedy.

xdSrY3DMN0nu7-6c3OFLnA.text: The banh mi and cafe sua da I picked up for lunch was really tasty. I queued for 25 minutes and observed a lot of the service chaos that was happening behind the counter amusingly because you know it's rush hour, deal with it. At one point, I watched a manager slam a re-order down at her sandwich makers because of a botched order. When my food came up, I grabbed my order ready to high tail it out of there but when I was outside and looked back into the window, there was said woman: desperately flailing her arms at me beckoning me to not eat that sandwich and come back in. I came back in, she said it was the wrong bread, brown not white. Grabbed it. Ran. Enjoyed it, but thoroughly beleaguered by the entire experience.Maybe it was just lunchtime? Everywhere on the web the reviews were so lovely. Was I fooled by the foodie bloggers? Maybe growing up in a Little Vietnam means that I'm spoiled when it comes to simple, authentic banh mi without the drama.

LRYmCCG2vQ9Nh0mrPmTxKA.text: I liked the broken rice.. even though the rice wasn't broken.  The grilled pork was nice though.Get in before 12:15 on a weekday if you want a seat for lunch.

YYtrIn3IoZZu_VafeD3fGg.text: I have previously attempted to dine at Banh mi bay 2 times and every single time is has been closed, although it states the opening hours at the front door, it was closed with no noticed stating why. This was really frustrating, and i think they should have been a bit more considerate and proffessional. However i manged to get my foot in the door today, and i can say all is forgiven!!lol....The menu was really good and the prices were even better. My partner and I dine out at least 2 times a week and we love to try out various foods and sink in the culture. We felt really welcomed and the decor was warm and vibrant. The young Vietnamese waitress was very polite, hospitable and all what we had hoped to expect. We really enjoyed the Vietnamese spring rolls, they are tasty and well presented. We also ordered summer rolls, altohugh we admit that we have tasted better, the summer rollls lacked a certain something along with the peanut dipping sauce. Their Banh Mi special also lacked in taste, and i will have to agree with a few reviews that there were too many different flavours going on that it was rather hard to really know what you were tasting and eating,also i really was not keen on the pork,it looked and taste slightly plastic!!! therefore it was difficult to savor certain tastes, i partically enjoyed the grilled beef banh mi, and it was simply grilled beef, picked veg and some sauce, ... Overall i would dine again, but the only downside was that it we felt slightly rushed by the waiters, and maybe not a place to stay and chit chat if thats what you want!! :) but i think its a place worth checking out.

hNHlQICLBx0FXyw2TEB7OQ.text: Banh Mi Bay's flat fried noodles are perfect on a hangover.  YES I WAS HUNGOVER AGAIN.  Don't judge me.  I'm 27, I live in London and I work in film.  And it's December.  Hangovers are a prerequisite.  Just give me paracetamol and leave me alone.Anyway, I'd managed to drag myself out of the house to meet my friend for lunch (an eventful journey: doing my makeup on the tube (because I needed a bit more recovery time before I allowed a mascara wand near my eye, and my alcohol-fogged brain decided that it would be better to sleep more and then brandish said implement on a moving train), a lady gave me a tissue to remove the ensuing smudges and then talked to me and I talked back and we were both LONDONERS but we had an actual conversation. It was weird. And then I went outside and fell over. See, eventful).  I was like "just give me food, I don't care where" but I was pleased with this choice since I went to Vietnam for six whole days in October and am therefore fully justified in my critique of their cuisine.The flat fried noodles were lovely; nice mix of veggies and pork, a bit greasy but in my addled state, exactly what I wanted.  My friend had the cold noodle salad which was light and delicious (obviously I tried it) and they cheerfully gave us extra bowls of sauce too.  Service is super fast and they have proper Vietnamese coffee.  It's a little weak, but the fact that you can even buy these tiny percolators of joy in central London makes me a happy bunny.The summer rolls were fab but the spring rolls a bit disappointing.  Good taste but too small, which meant that the ratio of filling to overly-fried outside seemed wrong and they had too much crunch and not enough internal softness.  And you only get three but they cost about £4.  Not ideal.It took me the better part of an hour to work out why the huge mirror over the stairs had a handle on the bottom and hinges on top.  I was convinced there was a secret compartment hidden in the brick wall before I realised that it was a wardrobe door hung sideways.  Doh.  The whole shabby chic thing they've got going on is a bit Kirstie Allsopp-tastic but works really well.I'm quite sure purists would insist that any Kingsland Road joint is infinitely more authentic than this.  But if you're after a yummy centrally-located sit-down lunch for under a tenner in pleasant surroundings then you could do an awful lot worse than Banh Mi Bay.

tiTkydRckqfsKfVuCnVyVA.text: I'm a seasoned lover of all things Pho. I've kept restaurants in business SINGLE HANDEDLY from ordering so much Pho. I was not impressed.I can't pinpoint what it was. The company (in the form of a huge group of Yelpers) was excellent. The food just didn't tickle my satisfaction bone. The raw beef pho was just adequate, nothing that knocked my socks off. It was better once I added a huge amount of hot sauce, but that could just be me. The smoothie I had was good but rather small for the price.The ambience of the place was more suited for a daytime cafe or coffeeshop  instead of an actual Pho restaurant.Meh, as the two stars label says...I've experienced better.

U6MU28ulomkmaipKcwxvaw.text: Like other reviewers, I popped into Banh Mi Bay with some of the lovely Yelp Crew.  I had been looking at it longingly while on many a bus trip and was happy when it was chosen as a gathering place.  That night, the company shined much brighter than the food.  I started my meal with a pork and prawn spring roll and was left wondering what was missing.  Not enough mint?  I don't know...but it wasn't that burst of freshness that I usually associate with spring rolls.  I expected the raw beef pho to turn my ideas about the place around, but alas, it didn't.  The noodles were too thick for my taste and the broth was just...lacking.  The dish was so ho hum, even after the addition of copius sriracha, that I didn't even finish it.  And I'm a girl who has no problem lifting a bowl of pho to my lips to make sure no broth goes to waste.   Oh well...back to the hunt for the perfect pho.  At least the conversation wasn't bland.

6TQc5cZ9mQO6ZRWh8hm78A.text: Fair warning: I don't think this review will be useful for non-vegetarians.I have eaten here twice, once for lunch (when I had one of their vegetarian sandwiches) and the second time at a Yelp event for dinner (when I had the stir fried tofu). The sandwich was nice, the price  reasonable, but in the end neither had a "wow" feeling, nor more important a sense of fulfillment. Basically we left, and ended up having another full lunch within two hours, which does tends to mitigate the cheapest of the original sandwich. The dinner options for those who don't eat meat are very limited. None of the Pho's can be made vegetarian (though the manager reassured me that this would change within a month or two - stay tuned). The tofu dish I ended up being really quite nasty, and not something I would want to repeat. The pluses here are a pleasant dining room, and very friendly and attentive service. The restaurant is quite small so it would be wise to book if you are going as a group. The meat dishes looked good to me, so I'd be very happy to update this review when the vegetarian options catch-up.

lk9rwjEjYrcrNj4lFDOs7w.text: Looking for a quick lunch during my break, I came to Banh Mi Bay on recommendation from a friend.  At first I was a bit doubtful, after being told it was a 10-15 minute walk from college - luckily I put aside all doubts and set off on the trek to be well rewarded! I loved the atmosphere inside the cafe - nothing like I expected a Vietnamese cafe to be like.  It's a perfect blend of eccentricity - what I can only describe as a quirky English cafe and tasty Vietnamese food.  I had a caramel shredded pork baguette on Vietnamese baguette - wow! Taste explosion! The pork is really well seasoned, and the shredded picked mooli is a really good combination.  And since I could get my whole lunch for less than a fiver to take away (being very used to paying over a fiver on a normal day), I'm more than happy to come back if I'm in the neighbourhood and will be tempting my husband along in tow.

nmMujjBIWn49heEX5D4syA.text: I'm in love with this place. Just a mere hop skip and jump away from Leather Lane (the clothes ladies, the clothes!) is this charming little Vietnamese restaurant with subtly sanded down chairs and tasteful statement wallpaper. Not only is the food really really tasty and very well priced, but the staff are so friendly and the atmosphere really nice and chilled out, making it a great place to eat in with friends or otherwise. (Note: they do offer takeaway, but not delivery... yet).I was first inspired to come in here, because they said they made Vietnamese baguettes. Now, for anyone who has ever been to Vietnam, you know what I'm talkin' bout. Those crunchy baguettes are like air-filled heaven-sent goodness and are just awesome. So looking for a taste of that, brought me here.However, I haven't actually tried the baguettes yet, as I have been far too busy sampling the pho, bun noodles and other things on the menu. All of which are scrumptious and mouthwatering good. The food tastes like it's more authentic than say Pho, and dare I say it, I seem to have realigned my loyalty to this place. Plus the portions are reasonably sized and the fresh juices are yummy. It's definitely my new favourite Vietnamese place.

5aSmwPqEJR7P0SP-mnTsyQ.text: Cute little Vietnamese cafe with decent bánh mì and other cafe dishes. I'm not sure about the sea-green coloured walled. The place is pretty packed during lunch with both eat-in diners and takeaway customers. With only a few tables (around 10), it's more of a takeaway place. If you're lucky enough to get a table, the service is pretty good. Things I've tried that I liked:1. com dac biet (special rice dish)The cha (meatloaf-like) is well-prepared, the "bi" is a bit on the dry side, and so is the rice. The dressing makes up for it. The lemongrass grilled pork is nicely done. Definitely an overall good dish. 2. bánh mì Probably the best I've had in London. It's a filled baguette with good filling. Recommend for takeaway. 3. Ca phe sua daVietnamese iced-coffee. They use condensed milk (good!) and it's quite close to what I'm used to in Little Saigon, California.If you're looking for Vietnamese food around this area, this is the one to try.

crgXBwWKY642cOzzR_i1WQ.text: I love this place for lunch takeout--I am especially in love with the beef baguette and it is a good deal, filling, spicy and delicious!  They are quick and awesome at lunch.Now sitting down for dinner was a bit if a disappointment.  The noodle dish I had (the one that they claim is usually for breakfast) was just ok, but also although the decor is cute, it just lacked dining atmosphere.So, when in the hood, grab a baguette for under 4 quid and walk away happy!

Qk5Ka1mxNgC3rdcrGsy9pA.text: The guy behind the counter recommended the Bahn Mi Bay Special, which includes pork pate, pork roll and spiced pork. They also have an option of a special Vietnamese baguette  it costs a bit more but is more authentic as it is made with rice flour rather than wheat.When I took a bite, I was a little disappointed by the bread-to-filling ratio  the flavors of the filling weren't punchy enough to stand up to all of the bread. I love all of the ingredients that go in, especially the pickled vegetables and cilantro, but for some reason everything tasted a bit muted. That said, it's still a bánh mì and so I still finished it  it just wasn't one that I would necessarily rave about or go back for.

E6VVmqOYjy6Ataa_6zb-Pg.text: Well colour me unenthused. I've walked by here a number of times and was so excited to try it out. A banh mi place so close to my house... brilliant! Sadly no.This place is mediocre, at best. Cold Vietnamese summer rolls with no real flavour. A bone dry baguette with three prawns and some rocket in it. So hard I actually broke a tooth on it, I'm not kidding. I've had better sandwiches at Subway. From the reports around the table, no one else was that enthused either. Banh mi Bay is alcohol free, but they have lots of juices. Just no booze. It really is a glorified sandwich shop. If you want banh mi, try that stall in Broadway Market.

1m3M5KuZUD9shJzDgotz0g.text: So happy I found a Vietnamese restaurant near campus!!!! Looking forward to enjoying bowls of pho on rainy days!!

_nhG1irWXwJOz3iVxjo7yA.text: This address is slightly out, is actually between Grey's Inn & John street

CqbldDAKMeOJUWIGePI-XQ.text: I'm a big fan of the great Vietnamese cuisine with all its herbs and spices so I had to give Banh Mi Bay a go after walking past it a number of times. My old time favourite dish is Bun Xa beef (vermicelli soup / salad with herbs etc) so I thought I'd go for something different and ordered a Banh Mi, the Vietnamese version of a baguette. It was lovely but felt almost like a Bun Xa stuffed into baguette. Anyway, I also decided to go for a glass of soya milk....word of warning: avoid! It was unsweetened and if you're not used to it, I would not recommend it. My waiter was absolutely lovely and put some syrup in it to make it drinkable much to the dismay of the Vietnamese lady behind the counter who looked like the big boss...errm: advise to the big boss: don't pull an unpleasant face about a customer when the customer can clearly see you!! Also please reply when the customer says: Thank you and good bye when they leave? Food is ok but won't be bringing my business back to rude management.

SrPVRWuoMZZ3KopZBTa2kA.text: Yum yum yum. Love the snacky menu. Fantastic, well seasoned chargrilled pork in my sandwich. Great place to stop for a bite and for something so different and tasty.

photos.caption: Photo of Banh Mi Bay - London, United Kingdom

1AvsEs6aPmXp44ExYLJ56Q.text: This place was decent. Not the greatest pho I have ever had. But for London Pho, this is alright. The portions are huge and good for the price. California pho is just too good so I won't even compare the two. This is good for a cold night for sure so come whenever you want to eat something warm.

G_DApvLLUvg8R-fznsUTHA.text: Noodles are good, sandwiches are good, but it's the Vietnamese coffee and desserts that keep me coming back! Sweet condensed milk with fresh, strong coffee slowly dripping into it - oh yes. The desserts do not sound appetising. And let's be honest, they don't look particularly appealing either. But the truth is they taste INCREDIBLE! Reading the dessert menu I found myself thinking 'Kidney beans in a dessert?!?! What the heck?!' or 'Black eyed peas in a pudding?!?! You must be kidding!'. Oh how I was mistaken. Somehow kidney beans with coconut cream, ice and homemade tapioca just works. It's hard to imagine, but true. You really have to try it. It's just so tasty. Yum yum yum.

MZ8au-nC1lrWaofEldhjWg.text: A newly acquainted friend recommended this place... so I just had their banh canh w/ crab and shrimp... Pretty good for London but doesn't compare to San Jose/San Francisco (where I'm from). It does have a nice "homey" broth to it... Would come back again for a quick Vietnamese bite!

RtWuw9JTSip9pG3_GFJ-MA.text: Had a craving for Banh Mi went to check this place out.  Got the Bay special baguette with Vietnamese bread.  It was awful. The bread was so stale and dry it ruined my whole lunch.  The pate didn't look very appetising it was dark and tasteless, I thought it would be pink.  The only thing that gave flavour was the chilli. Fillings were quite meagre and yes I agree with fellow Yelpers there is no wow factor. If you sell baguette sandwiches you should check everyday that your bread is not stale and if you think you can fob off stale bread to customers you'll never get repeat business.   I had high hopes based on the reviews I read but based on this experience I would never go here ever again.

sY8fJRsr-EgEDzvOrhpYNw.text: This attractive little Vietnamese eatery with a big menu featuring excellent baguette sandwiches just recently opened. I was lucky enough to happen upon Banh Mi Bay while running some errands over the weekend. Now a few days later, I'm craving a banh mi from here again. Unless something goes horribly wrong within the next hour, I'll heading there for lunch again today. Not only is this a yummy place but it's easy on the wallet too! £3.50 for an ample sandwich is awesome. The vast majority of Banh Mi Bay's dishes are at or under five quid with the most expensive being £7 for pork, prawn and crab noodle soup. See you there?

ng9FyDZIN1jM4bfiUHdjbQ.text: If Cafe East weren't here, this would be the best Vietnamese I've tried in London. Nice, un-busy interiors

mxXf9o_K6SIKP2S6cf_-tg.text: I've been hitting vietnamese restaurants at full force for the past few months. Not because its trendy but a lot of my friends suggest these places and I just tag along. (i fail as a yelp elite, I should be making the calls about where to go LOL)Anyways, Banh Mi Bay. I think their specialty lies in their banh mi's but I didn't try them since I went for an evening birthday meal. I don't think this place is great for birthdays at all, with most restaurants, you bring the cake, they open it, candles, bring it to your table. Service right? Not Banh Mi Bay! Apparently giving them the cakebox to put aside somewhere, that's not obvious at all. (if I wanted to take it out the box, I would've kept it on my table, no?!) Aside from the birthday misunderstanding, I was so disappointed with the bo tai pho. The broth was not rich enough at all, nor did they give me much chillis for my condiments dish. (I got 3 mini slices of mini chillis-not even a whole chilli!) and NO coriander. it's like they wanted my dish to be bland. Birthday Girl's Banh Canh noodle broth was much better. Im quite sad I didn't order that and a bun noodle dish (super summery!) was also good. Sounds like I got the bum deal. We also ordered summer rolls and a prawn salad, the latter lacked that extra sourness, it was REALLY sweet. Vietnamese coffee, as recommended by other yelpers was like a caffeine roundhouse kick to the face, super strong and super sweet. The Lemonade was essentially lemon cordial and sparking water, it was quite refreshing and zingy, I'll admit. Service was a bit haphazard, the staff seemed quite flustered by the fact we wanted to celebrate there and they seemed a bit awkward when we asked them to take some group photos.(my friends and I)It wasn't bad by any means, but I've definitely had better more generous vietnamese places.

86PfmRPnoQo9w9YXvoihww.text: This is by far my favourite place to go for lunch - I'll typically come here several times a week.  Staff are friendly and super efficient.  They even know my usual orders!  :OEverything is great here, affordable and tasty.  Rice boxes, banh mi, fried noodles, and noodle soups are all fantastic.  They just renovated and added more room for takeaway - a welcome change.  It gets so busy here at lunch that typically, before the renovation you would  have to smoosh into a corner to avoid being bowled over by some steaming hot pho.  (which given how yummy it is maybe that would be okay.)  I also like that they sell many of the ingredients they use - summer roll wrappers, sriracha sauce, fermented fish sauce.....    I will of course be returning, because I always do.

jY6kpjh_0Qqnz8u4uigFpg.text: Came here for an early dinner... the restaurant was decked in bright colours from the outside, which is a really refreshing sight in an otherwise dreary place. I ordered a pork shoulder noodle soup - forgot the Vietnamese name for it, but the noodle was a mixture between Udon and Silver Needle Noodles (Lao Shu Fen). Anyways the bowl cost £7.50 but the serving was surprisingly tiny. The soup was filled 3/4 of the bowl, but the noodles accounted for less than half. Honestly, I barely felt anything in my stomach after that. Really not worth the money at all.Also ordered Vietnamese iced coffee because the che ba mau was out of stock (disappointing!). As usual, the coffee is amazing and it cannot be faulted no matter how many different Vietnamese restaurants I go. You can not go wrong with condensed milk hahaha.In the end, because I wasn't full after a pricey £7.50 noodle, I ordered a Bay Special baguette to go. The baguette was amazing, but it would be better if it were served hot. Still, this is a way better alternative than a Pret sandwich which costs equally as much. However, only order the baguette if you're taking out, because eating-in costs another additional £1, making it a total of £4.95.

HqYO4c_snu6BE4I8qlbeSw.text: Nice little place, amazing food, reasonable prices and friendly staff. We had a small issue but the staff treated us with a smile and fixed the issue in a few minutes. Will definitely come back soon! Highly recommended!

XaIeV952U23zGfKD2TTtJA.text: We visited this restaurant for a taste of the famous Banh Mi sandwich. It did not disappoint. We also enough the summer rolls, and found the staff to be very attentive! The pho was nice as well, though not the very best I have had. I'd certainly stop by for another sandwich in the future!

-jBJY7k7oVqlyYIz-cKr_A.text: On the suggestion of some classmates, a big group of us popped in a few days ago for lunch. We started out as six... then became 12... then were 18, and Bahn Mi Bay managed to successfully adapt to our huge group, take our orders and bring food with great speed and service, and keep a great attitude about a huge group arriving without reservation and in the middle of the lunch rush. Well done on that last bit.I have never had Vietnamese before (and in fact didn't really this time either, opting for a respectable chicken curry), but those who had say the Pho is top notch, with generous portions and a great assortment of fresh ingredients. My Vietnamese spring rolls were quite small, but very savory. The chicken curry with baguette was tasty and rich. Primarily, though, I was impressed by the service, and have heard from others that this is the place to go for great service. Being in a convenient spot for lunch meetings, I think it's quite likely I'll be back. Definitely going for the Pho next time.

bErkbyHLAPtQZTN0DhHkpA.text: Banh Mi Bay: I really want to like you, but you're just not quite hitting it. The pho is more or less on point -a little flat - but they definitely get props for offering a vegetarian version which is something you don't see too often.  The banh mi are decent too, but could be a little more generous with the fillings. My lady had the vegetarian bun tau hu chay  the last time we went but was unimpressed - they'd gone too light on the mint and coriander. Compared to say a grilled pork version, a tofu version is always gonna have a bit more work to do on the flavour front so there's no excuse for holding back on the elements that would give it a fighting chance.Service can be a bit patchy as well - if it's busy be prepared to get your wave on.Overall, Banh Mi Bay is OK, but it won't blow your mind. Price-wise it's relatively cheap but eating in nudges the price up enough to make you wonder whether you're being played, just a little bit. A little bit of extra effort and thought and these guys could smash it.

eJzgBdsoB9DxAiILUTBDsw.text: Good food. Somewhat attentive staff. Would go again given the proximity to where I work.

m-2aeTzMqAWNfv3OQkt1LQ.text: This is really a great place to go if you fancy treating yourself to something really truly delicious. Their Satay Chicken rice box is a firm favourite of mine, all freshly cooked and very generous portion sizes. I am no connoisseur when it comes to Vietnamese food, I just know that everything I have tried here has been super yummy.

MX9vImy8_0AGBgW-aQ08gQ.text: £3.50 a sandwich in Farringdon? Yes please! Here you'll find bánh mì made pretty damn well and their tofu bun noodle salad... well, move over Pho, this is my new favourite place. The only thing they fall down on is their Viet iced coffees, again these are not strong enough and far too sweet.At lunch time, you'll see a line out the door, and so there sound be - this place rocks. With Grey's Inn Fields just across the road, it makes this the most perfect summer lunchtime spot. You grab your yummy, cheap food and head on over to the park. Forget eating at your desk - for 45 minutes you'll feel like you're on holiday with fabulous food and sunshine. A winner all round.

evJbU9GYpNRtK-1R9aI9Lw.text: Punching above its weight. Lovely decor, great authentic food and friendly service. Rich tasty broth in the Pho, fantastic pork spring rolls. Will be back.

2JUG9D13LimVCBom1eULFA.text: Lovely, pleasant interiors and the food was good.  We had the grilled mix meats with rice (which were lovely but a little under seasoned), bun bo hue (again good if a little under seasoned), and the classic banh mi (again it was tasty but the baguette wasn't crunchy enough the way a Vietnamese baguette should be).  On the whole, the food was good but each dish missed a vital element which prevented it from being memorable or worth a repeat visit (unless you live or work in the area, in which case it is perfectly acceptable).  My biggest issue was the bun bo hue which needed more aroma and seasoning, and the cut of beef used needed way more cooking to make it tender.

sP4txbTnzBjTKGzq6l4UAA.text: Only been the one time, but the caramel pork viet baguette was most impressive, proper portions of meat, mooli, coriander, chilli, carrot etc and £3.50 - you pay more for some of the stuff in M&S and it doesnt stand up to this placeIf your in the area check it out for lunch, I will be back to go through the rest of the menu...

8LlwiZ-84r5-WShIytobCQ.text: I'd been dying to check this place out after all the Yelp raves but meh...Maybe it was an off day for them? But I ordered the banh canh (udon noodles with crab meat) and it was really salty - I pretty much downed my carrot and ginger juice in one go. Maybe I should've gone for the pho?Will give this a go again and re-write this review if necessary, but so far, not impressed....

n3vmztwy8SZKVCwh4wxlFg.text: I passed by the restaurant look quite cozy and tried their famous Vietnamese Pho but the noodle is not really traditional Pho and the soup is tasteless. I would prefer Pho from Viet Eat which is not quite far from here.

-9AE4sW5x3zMR6Lukv368w.text: Since I've moved to London I have been searching for all the foods that remind me of home in California, One of which include vietnamese sandwiches.if you are not familiar with this sort of sandwich, let me clue you in - it's a taste sensation!French baguette filled with pickled carrots/radish/cucmbers, cilantro or coriander, green chili pepper, butter, soy sauce (just a drip), and your choice of whatever meats! I always get bbq pork or chicken, which is grilled meat with an asian type of seasoning. Banh Mi Bay is only a 5 min walk from my work, so I try to make a trip out here every week to order their grilled bbq pork sandwich which is only £3!I love how they are not stingy about the amount of meat, and that the french baguette doesn't tear the roof of your mouth at every bite. Anyways, check this place out for the sandwiches. Not sure yet about the other items on the menu but for good pho i usually go to Mien Tay i nClapha.

6UgCgWzUwpkXLmKyiqeviA.text: Best Vietnamese sandwiches I've had in London.  Definitely was missing the banh mi after exiting Northern California (noticed many other Yelpers felt similarly!) but have now had my fix.The Vietnamese baguettes--made in-house--are not to be missed.  Their French baguettes aren't bad either, but the Vietnamese ones are what you really want.  Fresh, fresh, fresh, and slightly crispy on the outside, soft and doughy on the inside.  Make sure you try a sandwich that has pate!  I'm not at all a big pate fan, but something about the pate here has my taste buds singing.  I don't even know what usually seasons pate and have no idea what Banh Mi Bay does to theirs, but it is a must-try.  The grilled meats are all nice and tender, so you basically can't go wrong, whichever one you choose.  Can't comment much on the hot food, unfortunately, except to say that my dinner companion enjoyed her noodles (can't remember which one).  Still, this place is worth checking out for the banh mi alone, which is only right for an establishment called Banh Mi Bay.

Y3wCyq6wPAM8rEyO4jBajw.text: I had the vegetable spring rolls and the daily vegetable soup. The spring rolls were TINY, tasteless and doughy, the soup had a few spinach leaves floating on top and the rest was clear broth (quite tasty broth, but no more filling for that). Paid £6 for this and was genuinely disappointed with my lunch.

photos.caption: Photo of Banh Mi Bay - London, United Kingdom. Hand-to-spring roll ratio - and I have quite slim hands!

gcp1aUgqKSpKqPIbEbr6QQ.text: Having spent a day exploring museums. Came across this by chance and can only say it was a bit of luck. Friendly staff welcomed us and recommended what to try, be warned though when they say it is spicy, it is hot! Prices are inexpensive. Try it and see

5tOSAmTi0MFsP8QJ86ovjw.text: Since we can't make it to the yelp event; let's bring yelp to us.  With various pre-dinner email exchanges, including "WTF you are taking us to a SANDWICH shop for Friday dinner"; we trooped off to a restaurant exactly 5 mins walk away from apparently where most of my friends work.The rolls were yummy and the pho were good (the beef was actually raw as per advertised!!!) but they seem to need to add a bit more rice flour or whatever that keeps noodles from not sticking as mine were slightly balled and glued up.  Ditto for the rolls.  They are massive so I'd rather you cut it up for me as well.  The brown gunk (whatever that was) wasn't too tasty and our pho did come with hoisin sauce... which is new; I like hoisin sauce though, so whatever.The highlight of the meal was defo the sandwiches with everyone proclaiming that they'd come back for lunch since it was a nice little restaurant and only around 4 squids for a fresh french baguette sandwich.  Unfortunately they were sold out of the viet baguette so can't tell you what that was like.No alcohol license yet; but as Li-mei said; they are super chill so do feel free to BYO for the mo and good selection of asian soft drinks of offer as well.

8fP09ToQqIkpbA4a9KGZrA.text: Really disappointing - went with a big party,All the food came at different times (15 min gap between two) and ordered coffees that just did not arrived even after asking twice. Not the best atmosphere either, wouldn't bother.

N1PtMk0n_YIeNgF4cSFN5A.text: We got into the bánh mì thing whilst living in NYC where Vietnamese sandwich shops where popping up all over the place.  Anyhow we were in Bloomsbury over the weekend and saw a Pret on one corner and a Vietnamese sandwich shop across the intersection.  Our curiosity led us into Bánh Mì Bay and we were duly rewarded.these guys have quite a few things on the menu including pho, salads, rice boxes, Vietnamese coffee etc. etc., however, we were there for one reason only...The waitress recommended their special Banh Mi called the Dac Biet (pate, spiced pork) and the wife got the Banh Mi Tom Nuong (Chargrilled Prawn).  Wow these sandwich really pack in the flavour!  The might not have been as juicy and rich as the ones we were used to in NYC, but in fairness they somehow tasted fresher and more healthy which is a win win.  Can't wait to go back!

photos.caption: Photo of Banh Mi Bay - London, United Kingdom. Beef pho and some warming green tea

onGWh3XMQtLb-e_8G5uiLg.text: its a bit overpriced, typically of London. I first came across banh mi living in australia and in a country known for being ridiculously expensive these always hit the spot and were a bargain, no pate tho!.the quality is the same, if not better and everything was bloody tasty. the various noodles are also very very good. could do with some extra spice and perhaps some citrus?good work lunch spot.

photos.caption: Photo of Banh Mi Bay - London, United Kingdom. pork roll

zaVwBbc3palljbgNWCIFug.text: Do NOT get their pho.It is a horrible representation of the popular Vietnamese noodle soup and if you actually think that it tastes good, then you don't know what you're missing out on. I highly doubt I will find a pho place in London that will even compare to pho in California, but I won't burn that bridge yet.Banh Mi Bay is down the street from my school so I find myself here quite a bit. Their broken rice dishes are actually really good and based on my experience with their pho, I will gladly order their rice dishes any day. I've tried the grilled chicken and grilled pork and both are tasty. The pho is unbearably bland and you're going to have to douse it in hoisin and sriracha to give it some flavor. Instead of pho they should really call it noodles in hot water with meat. But other than that, the service is pretty quick and everything else I tried isn't half bad. The restaurant is clean and they're open for lunch and reopen for dinner around 5:30PM. Just an FYI, since I tried going there after class one day and I had to wait til they opened for dinner.

meKVLkp4CeBiBTo1VnkUGg.text: Duped out of 6P again.  I don't know why I've been here more than once.  The pho is lousy w/ small portions compared to other Vietnamese restaurants around and to the East.  I am currently sitting eating a pretty poor lemongrass beef w/ overcooked rice.  Again, portions and quality just aren't there.  Most mall food courts are better than this.People, we can do better!

NfSqAd2b527GhPc4ptIUqQ.text: This place is not exactly a 4 stars, more like 3.5. However, my standards are high because I am Vietnamese and had some great Vietnamese food in my life. I ordered the vegan pho and vegetarian banh mi. The pho was okay but did warm me up from the cold. The banh mi was better.

UVI7yjNzcbBxjPIvD8qTog.text: First time I came here I liked it although was slightly underwhelmed. Didn't love the summer roll but I think I got one with a weird filling.Anyway, came back today and randomly decided to try the tiger prawn banh mi. The prawns were freshly cooked and seriously delicious, really punchy flavour which blended so so deliciously with the pickled carrots. I really savoured it. Also, whereas the first time I came here I didn't really like the bread today it was really good. Fresh, crispy, even the bit that didn't have any sauce/filling involved (which normally just makes me sad). Friendly service, pretty decor, great value for money.What would really make the sandwiches perfect is: more filling. Now I know that makes me sound greedy, but it's really all about the savouring, and getting the right balance of flavour between the filling and the bread, blah blah just bring me more prawns.

IIXTA2_AzSr5evEqO-M5eg.text: Bánh Mì Bay-be! Vietnamese coffee for £1! Oh and summer rolls, so fresh at ten to noon, why I'll have two! There's an almost zen-like calming atmosphere in here when food is meditatively prepared before the hullabaloo, the lunacy of the lunch rush when suity types start flooding in. I've no prejudices against these guys, they have to eat too and I can admire their choice of where to take their clients and a comedy cuff-link as much as the next girl. This one, In mid-town where relaxed casual creatives meet to eat opposite their slick city counterparts, is where I on the tattier side of latter, felt more comfortable taking a take-away.  So don't ban me, Bánh Mì that'd be the worst thing to happen. This place is delicious, friendly and fresh! They were also doing a BOGOF on Saigon Coffee Co take home ground coffee the last time I went.

OTQyMILoboGk-PoPGnFSAA.text: It's a tough call but I think Banh Mi Bay edges out Pho as my favorite Vietnamese restaurant in Farringdon. Great tasty sandwiches---be sure to get #2, the pulled caramel pork---sweet, spicy, and simply delicious---the perfect summertime baguette. Banh Mi Bay draws in the lunch crowd, so get there early to snag a table or be prepared to get your sandwich to go. I've been twice now for lunch and both times got variations of a pork sandwich which is a relative bargain at £3.50. Next time I will have to try one of the mains as they looked great (a wide assortments of soups and grilled meats are on the menu) but are more appropriate for dining in. The restaurant looks more like a pastel green colored English tea room than a Vietnamese cafe.

photos.caption: Photo of Banh Mi Bay - London, United Kingdom

3l-dbZbaIfy6gRqNtOX9nA.text: This place received many of my hard earned coins being so close to campus. Lunch for a fiver is the way to go when you're a struggling uni student AND sriracha!!They also had vietnamese coffee for about the same price as the coffee places around the area, but much stronger. Also elixer much sought after by uni students. If I planned it correctly, I could have dinner, and a post dinner coffee all waiting for me when I got out of class... I was always quite chuffed at my efficiency.I did get fancy a few times and actually sit in, usually pretty full for dinner. It should be known that sitting in is about 2 quid more than taking out and I believe it's a similar menu. They do have apps and such that aren't on their board of course, but same thing for the most part. Pho is quite good as well. When a place messes up pho, I don't know if I can trust anything else on their menu, but they do quite well here. Many good eats and convos had here.

dcALxWJgKlN6a3CjZ0J4-Q.text: I visited Banh Mi Bay after I was told all of the vegetarian options were vegan (or could easily be made so). Between two people, we ordered vegan banh mi, pho chay, and bun noodles.At the very least I expect a hint of cinnamon and anise in any pho, but this one tasted of pure vegetable stock cube and lacked any depth. Maybe my expectations are out of line, but based on other places I've eaten both in Vietnam and elsewhere, I think Banh Mi Bay skimped on the fresh herbs and chillies.The bun noodles were passable, but the sauce didn't have the punch I expect from this dish. The sandwich was the highlight of the meal, mainly because the baguette was good. The service was really good and the staff very friendly and welcoming, and I enjoyed the open kitchen concept, but the food was lacklustre. I might return for the sandwich if I was in the area, but that's it.Someone with less experience of Vietnamese food and/or an appreciation for mellow and toned down flavours may find this place more to their liking...

FCsurXN9azC2Og1_XEwHpQ.text: A solid 3.5 stars for Banh Mi Bay. That being said, I never have the heart to give three stars when I think it's a bit better.If you happen to be walking in the area and you haven't quite made it towards Kingsland Road or Soho yet where you'll find a number of lovely Vietnamese places, and you really want Pho, it's by all means a good fix for those with a Pho craving.  The place is cute and clean.Rare beef pho is one of my favorites.

U4KFJvX5Un-_lyStJ1P-kg.text: Determined, I went on a Pho hunt as soon as I became homesick. Coming from an area where Asian minorities are indeed the majority, I had become unaware that not everywhere in the world was as privileged as myself and all of my fellow Northern Californians. Soon enough, I had found myself salivating over thoughts of steaming bowls of my favorite Vietnamese soups and dishes. Hell, I was going bonkers just to smell the familiar scent of dipping fish sauce that is just so perfect when the moment is right. I had listed Banh Mi Bay on my list to try and, so far, it has been my favorite. Compared to a lot of the other places, their menu has far more variety, and they capture the flavors more impressively. Their pho noodles are still a bit wider than they should be, but sometimes you just have to accept what you have in front of you. Honestly, I was already happy when I saw that they used real hoisin sauce, real Sriracha, and served all the right accompanying vegetables. Plus, the owners are Vietnamese. =)I've managed to get a group of people from work, which is conveniently located only a 5 minutes walk away, completely hooked on this restaurant and they have passed their friends along as well. Between all of us, we've tried the chicken and beef Phos, the crab and combination Banh Canhs, the Spring Rolls, some Vietnamese sandwiches, and their tri-colored dessert. I can assure you that we have loved them all, except maybe the last. And, really, what's not to love about a restaurant that's open late on Sundays? Wait, correction: What's not to love about a restaurant that is open on Sundays?!Note to owners if you are reading this: please add soda xi muoi to your menu!

photos.caption: Photo of Banh Mi Bay - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Banh Mi Bay - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Banh Mi Bay - London, United Kingdom

VJ-Z3SBUP48PGYeF8dh1Bg.text: Popped in for lunch as I was in the area and starving. For what it is, the prices were a little on the steep side, but given the area, that's normal. I had the Chicken Satay Bun and was really pleased. Good flavour, the sauce that came with it was just right and had that lovely fish sauce tang to it, and the chicken was beautiful. I really liked it. My partner had a Spiced Pork Baguette and like it well enough. He said it was good, that he really like the pork, but that the Bahn Mi he had at Ziloufs (Islington) was better. the Vietnamese green tea is pretty good, and it's actual loose leaf, unlike many other restaurants. All in all, if I were in the area, I'd probably drop in again. I wouldn't go out of my way for it, though. Plenty of other really good Vietnamese joints that are a little cheaper and more conveniently located for me. We spent 15.55 on two mains and two teas. Not dirt cheap, but not pricey.

peDxCAU1eTKL0MEwlA30Hg.text: My first day in the UK and I was craving something from home that I was missing. Growing up in a vietnamese community in California, I was craving pho. I remember all my friends telling me never to eat pho in England so I had such low expectations and when I went in blindly to this restaurant, they really exceeded my expectations. I had a pho tai and it was delicious! Best 8 pounds ever spent! Reminds me of home and my moms home cooking! Definitely coming back sometime soon!

OHHOfiDApzs5WuG1gfUC7w.text: Erm. I was a little disappointed by Banh Mi Bay. The food's just so-so and, in truth, it's more expensive that the Vietnamese places in Shoreditch, which aren't too far away. I've been here twice now and had a noodle dish the first time around which was of a decent size and filled me up nicely. The second time, I had a banh mi, which turned out to be on the small side. I ended up ordering a side of summer rolls just so I wouldn't go hungry. If I hadn't been to Keu, I wouldn't have minded. But I have, and Keu offers much better tasting and more substantial banh mi than this place does. So, if it's banh mi you're looking, just take the short bus trip to Keu. You'll be far better off for it.

photos.caption: Photo of Banh Mi Bay - London, United Kingdom

AV60cZiib9G0PjuzEKD4hQ.text: I came here starving after the worst audition of my life and wanted to eat the whole restaurant. But I didn't. And I settled n the chicken lemongrass curry with steamed rice. I would describe it as a-ok!! And the potatoes in it were my favourite part... my favourite thing about Vietnamese food is that you don't feel all full and car by like you do when you have a Chinese or an Indian...its just lighter and healthier! Friendly service too..and cheap!

DatazMCsgFwEG3B9gqSg9Q.text: The tender beef brisket pho here is just the best. Now I've not had a lot of pho in my time but the flakey, buttery soft, delicious Pho at Banh Mi Bay just keeps me coming back for more and more and more. So much, in fact, that I've had to rein in my pho addiction in order to try to save money.A chap called Tony introduced me to Banh Mi Bay one day when we were on the way to conference down the road (we work on Vine Hill) and it was on the way. He treated me to pho and now we will be friends for ever. Me and the pho I mean. Me and Tony are gonna be friends for a while but it's really just a work thing because he's got too much hair.I've not had anything else off their menu. Just pho. But I give it five stars. Five big, fat stars.

fpqMLoOSZqX4F_E_BsParw.text: Finally tried one of the Banh Mi from here today. I had the "Bay Special" on Vietnamese bread. £3.50. My boyfriend had the caramel pork. Get the Bay Special! Oh my. It was incredible.It was very, very busy at 1 o'clock today, we had to queue to take away and it didn't look like there would be much chance of getting a table any time soon. That's okay though. A lot of things can be forgiven for sandwiches like this. Inside the decor is very cute, Farrow and Ball type colours on the walls and exposed brickwork and pretty lighting. Definitely more a cafe atmosphere than an evening out feel though. I'm just so glad someone is doing Banh Mi in this part of London. I'll be back!

0q9F-8OmSLztWXFYbHWbDQ.text: As a true lover of vietnamese food (when living in NYC I went to every vietnamese restaurant in manhattan and most in Queens) this is the absolute best Vietnamese in the area. Mmmm pho. Only 4 stars as sometimes the service can be a little difficult (you get the food, but not the bill...) But wonderful place.

JRw0_EuaMv7ooO-VnrFX6Q.text: Nice looking restaurant with a relaxed vibe. Because of the grill open kitchen near the entrance, the noise level is a bit higher. The rare beef and cooked beef pho is nice but rare beef isn't exactly rare when they came. The cooked beef on the other hand is cooled through and very tasty. I also ordered avocado and kiwi juice, freshly made you can see the fruit bits - loved it. Overall 4* experience, great for a chilled night hanging out with friends.

Yx59kew_v_3FWVMQJWnDOQ.text: Up there with the Newcommen-Watt steam engine and the invention of human rights among the eighteenth century's foremost contributions to modern life, the sandwich is so much more than the sum of its parts. Practical, ubiquitous, and frequently - if not universally - delicious, the sandwich is one of life's great constants. And yet at the same time, versatility is key to its appeal, offering a doughy canvass for the world's culinary diversity. Does anything better embody this than banh mi? There's something truly inspired about that one-two punch of rich, sweet pork fat and the zing of coriander-laced vegetables, all sinking into rice-soft dough. Almost enough to temporarily turn one into an apologist for the sins of French colonialism. Throw in the inherent fun of its 'street food' mental associations, and there are few better prospects for lunch-on-the-go.Banh Mi Bay's 'Bay Special' was a solid fix to my recent cravings, but by no means exemplary. While undoubtedly a good sandwich, it still left significant room for improvement. The pate could have creamier, the caramel-glazed ham more flavourful. Above all, the small dose of coriander and lack of any discernible seasoning or sauce deprived this banh mi of its characteristic freshness. At £5.95, it was reasonable, without quite being good value. All in all, a solid lunch, but not a day-changing one.

photos.caption: Photo of Banh Mi Bay - London, United Kingdom

_zWM7Sj4oU0VdF9qSu6jAA.text: Very decent Vietnamese good in a central location. It's chilled out and laid back. The food is really 3.5 stars and very fresh. That said, nothing was a standout. Summer rolls were refreshing but lacked a little oomph. Vietnamese pancakes needed to be crisper and better lettuce (no thank you iceberg lettuce hearts). Steamed veg was a little boring (ok, it's steamed veg, I get it) but the dipping sauce was flavoursome. The prawn bun had no sauce so we ended up compensating with other stuff on our table from other dishes. The also annoyingly brought everything at the same time. Seriously, it was a small table. Couldn't you have staggered the dishes?!  I would recommend ordering your starters and then ordering any mains. We struggled to fit everything on our table and needed to put the wine bottle on the floor.

RoEFkCNA8mlwLhNMaD5TcQ.text: This place claims to have brought Banh Mi to the London food scene and it delivers. I grabbed a Banh Mi for lunch and it was made quick despite the surge of customers around noon. Specifically, I ordered a Banh Mi Chicken Satay and was hesitant since they deviate from the traditional Banh Mi protein options. The veggies were fresh and the Satay was a bit on the dry side. Altogether, this place offers legitimate Banh Mi and I'd consider it a must if want to munch on a budget.

photos.caption: Photo of Banh Mi Bay - London, United Kingdom

8ciD5zNb0T5mMR7vj_EuTg.text: My friend and I got the brisket pho and a pork Bhan mi, and we shared. They were so good! I would unreservedly recommend this place for an outing with friends and family. It is reasonably priced. The atmosphere is nice, and the decor is cute and chic. The place can use a little bit of more customers. Perhaps entice the college crowd with some discounts. [Hint. Hint. Wink. Wink.]

photos.caption: Photo of Banh Mi Bay - London, United Kingdom. Wine menu.
Photo of Banh Mi Bay - London, United Kingdom. Soft drinks. I think they're freshly made.
Photo of Banh Mi Bay - London, United Kingdom. Appetizers etc.

WLgfAfnHmS7pThpASkFTfw.text: Came during the lunch crush but still got seated quickly at a two-table. I had the tender beef brisket pho noodle in beef broth and my date had the spiced pork banh mi. They came quickly and were delicious - I couldn't finish mine it was so filling and flavorful. Not much to improve on here as it was tasty, affordable, fast. Well done BMB.

LEZ4hCwEFcOkfUHRnNvqtw.text: Banh Mi Bay is a bit further than most of my other regular lunch spots...but their food is so good that it is worth an extra bit of exercise.So far I have only tried the take-away noodles with satay chicken and the bay special sandwich (full of porky goodness.) They were both yummy enough to make me into an instant fan.The only problem is this place is BUSY at lunch time and so the take-away line often goes out of the door. They are very speedy at putting orders together...but it's all a bit of an un-organised jumble... so you might have to wait a while to receive your lunch! *It seems my yelp friends have all reviewed this place yeeears ago! I am so late to the party!!*

photos.caption: Photo of Banh Mi Bay - London, United Kingdom. Fishy noodles. Yum.
Photo of Banh Mi Bay - London, United Kingdom. Satay chicken & noodles.

dGtsqAhNk5vawX4v8CTO2g.text: I've come to Banh Mi Bay a couple times now for pho and it has been pretty good! Compared to the pho back home in the states, the broth is very comparable and they had all of the fixings, too. The noodles were wide noodles instead of skinny vermicelli noodles which was surprising but I've found that all pho restaurants in London use these noodles. I missed the skinny noodles but overall this place holds up okay! I've also ordered their spring rolls which are very tasty as well, though kind of expensive for only three spring rolls. Nonetheless, the location is great and the food is good. I'll be back!

KmOd0RAvl4fWrAUkBYwwjw.text: Been meaning to check this place out for a while now, and I finally did today. I walked away with two banh mi, one being tofu and the other being shrimp. The shrimp was entirely new to me, as I usually get pate at Lee's in the states. But it was good overall.The atmosphere wasn't your typical place, a bit nicer actually. I liked the location being so close to the bus and the service was quick. I'll be back!

photos.caption: Photo of Banh Mi Bay - London, United Kingdom. Shrimp banh mi
Photo of Banh Mi Bay - London, United Kingdom. Table for one please!

bvMN17b55jmNWQfWk4flxg.text: It's 2min away from my office and it's one of the best Vietnamese food I've had in London. The grilled pork is my favourite and I love the pickled vegetables on the side. It gets super busy in the afternoon during weekdays with all the city workers but you can opt for take out if you're in a rush. Although the table services are pretty quick too (the ladies there are super efficient) The only critique is that you'll come out smelling like food a bit :)

Y6LqdWHWXas--c9RnuxvEw.text: It's...ok.I always feel pretty healthy when I have Vietnamese food (brothy soup! Clean noodles! Pickled veg!) (NB: don't correct me if this is totally wrong). Banh Mi Bay is not a _bad_ option. But, well...it's not the best, either.It's fast, and it's fresh, and it's really affordable. Tofu bun noodle salad is a good choice. Pho is PHOINE (fine? Yeah?). It's fine. I appreciate that when you get takeaway that all the individual things are separately packaged up (bean sprouts in a little baggie, hoisin in a little cup). They have specials of the week but, otherwise, it's a pretty stripped down menu of Vietnamese go-tos (spring rolls, range of buns, rice dishes, phos and banh mi). Which is fine for someone as indecisive as I am.Not a place I'd ever make as a destination spot, but totally fine as an option if you happen to find yourself hungry and standing in front of it.Yelp note: significant discounts if you get take-away so, on a nice day, do so: many great nearby options for a picnic!

1x_8xiKwJNqkBglTwAOMqg.text: Perfectly decent Pho, nothing to shout about. Meat is boneless unlike some other places that just serve you the bones!It's cheaper if you get takeaway so consider that. Food arrives quickly, however it's brought from downstairs giving you the fear that the person bringing it up may fall and drop it all. I'm sure this doesn't happen often...I've heard that the Bahn Mi is actually their signature dish, so will need to try this on my next visit and update this score. We were seated at the middle of the restaurant and when it's lunchtime it can get quite annoying as you'll be surrounded by the lunch crowd looking to get their takeaway.

photos.caption: Photo of Banh Mi Bay - London, United Kingdom. Chicken pho

ECzJcw0tz94zPM_ds9mqEg.text: Tasty vegetarian spring rolls and great chicken pho. Food came out fast and service was good. Nice environment and not too expensive. Would come back again!

vy8_DDVQDYX6ngZ4AA4GnQ.text: Man Oh Man had I forgotten all about this place! I used to frequent this restaurant more than my bathroom..wait..that's weird but you get the picture!Their spring rolls are to DIEEEEEEEE for so flavoursome and their pan friend noodles with prawns are so packed with flavour I was convinced that I was in Vietnam! If it hadn't been for the balding Englishman across from me I would've bought the illusion!! Price wise they're not cheap but they're not expensive so it's a little Inbetween I'd say. So yup if you ever want a trip to Vietnam but can't afford the pricey plane fare then head on here baby!

KEYaQdfdVshj7ndKHCcKnw.text: Went for pho, summer rolls and pan fried pork. Everything was solid but slightly disappointing relative to the high expectations I had. For one, I wish my pho were served hotter. It came somewhat lukewarm which is always disappointing. Also, I felt like there was too much more noodles than soup. Having said that, it was still good, so a good place for a quick pho fix. The sides were all solid as well. A pleasant surprise was the pan fried pork, which almost reminded me of Korean bbq meat. Service was good. The waitresses were prompt and kind. I really liked the ambience -- homey and cozy yet spacious too!

SUW2JVdlwHanj_FFpvURbQ.text: Came here for a quick lunch after exploring the British History Museum. We arrived at about 12 pm and the place was at 50% capacity. By 12:30 pm the place was packed with only standing room!I ordered the vegetarian pho and it was awesome. The noodles were perfectly cooked and the carrots, red chili slices, thai basil, mint, lemon grass, spouts and spring onions were a lovely accompaniment to the dish. Did I mention they have Sriracha bottles on each table? Extra points!

photos.caption: Photo of Banh Mi Bay - London, United Kingdom. Veg Pho

pToNuHb0d4Uypn89Pq_TFg.text: The Pho is good, summer roll also. and they have soy milk.

tGBJpdzavMqLL7F_IirBEg.text: The food was average. Got the roast pork banh mi and summer rolls. Nothing memorable.What was memorable, however, was the horrible service. The cashier was rude and not helpful. Yes, lunch is a busy time, but that's no excuse to be rude. The cashier was rushing me and got really nasty about my signature for the credit card receipt. When he saw that the signature didn't match the card exactly, he immediately berated me saying that he can't accept it and was almost flipping out. I just calmly corrected it since it was no big deal, but he was just horrible about it.

T3OycaBHmUg4x7zgg6lNkw.text: Visited this Vietnamese restaurant on a lazy Saturday afternoon after heading to Hatton Gardens to resize my ring, my boyfriend has been here the year before, he was hungry, and he wanted to come here over my suggestion of going to Kimchi nearer Hoborn! I was expecting something good.We ordered:-Goi Cuon - Summer Rolls Tiger prawns, sliced pork, rice vermicelli, lettuce and Vietnamese herbs wrapped in rice paper, served with a peanut hoi sin dipping sauce. Pho noodle soup for my boyfriend (sorry don't know which one he ordered, some sort of beef)Bun Vermicelli Noodle Salad (Ga Sate - Chargrilled Satay Chicken)2x Vietnamese iced coffee.Comments:The summer rolls were so and so, tasted really bland. The prawn was big, which I appreciated, but the only flavour is only coming from the dipping sauce.My boyfriend's Pho unfortunately came with lukewarm soup. It was really disappointing. The meat tasted pretty nice but noone wants lukewarm meals. We scouted other tables who ordered Pho after us and their noodle soups were steaming hot! That's inconsistency right there for you.My vermicelli noodle salad was ok, I like the one at Cafe East more. The chicken was pretty dry, but I was hungry.The iced coffee was really strong. They don't use the Truong brand that I am used to, and they seem to put less condensed milk in as well, so it tasted more bitter than usual.The worst thing is by the time we left, I was already feeling ill. By the time we got home about 30-40 min later, both of us were throwing up and on the toilet in general. I really don't want to come back here :( It's not like the food was anything spectacular, and I think it has some hygiene issues perhaps.

photos.caption: Photo of Banh Mi Bay - London, United Kingdom. Iced coffee
Photo of Banh Mi Bay - London, United Kingdom

pc5c8bZsPQso_-U3Ht4x8Q.text: My friend and I ordered flat rice noodle dishes which we both found to be extremely salty. The summer rolls are lovely and fresh though. Staff are friendly and after a mix up of orders, they accepted the error and apologised for the mistake. However, I won't be going back to this place in a hurry.

photos.caption: Photo of Banh Mi Bay - London, United Kingdom. Prawn flat rice noodles and summer rolls
